articles.headline: New Kidnapping Reported in Nigeria as U.S. Offers Help
articles.snippet: The abduction of at least eight more girls came as the Obama administration announced that it had offered to help find and prosecute those responsible for the mass abduction last month, claimed by the Boko Haram extremist group.
articles.abstract: The abduction of at least eight more girls came as the Obama administration announced that it had offered to help find and prosecute those responsible for the mass abduction last month, claimed by the Boko Haram extremist group.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria — A second kidnapping of schoolgirls in Nigeria’s northeast by Islamist militants put new pressure on the country’s troubled government, which had been hoping to showcase its emergence as Africa’s largest economy this week but instead has been forced to confront its failure to contain a growing insurgency in its north.

articles.headline: A Singing Nun for a Reality TV World
articles.snippet: Sister Cristina Scuccia has become a sensation on the Italian version of the talent show “The Voice.”
articles.abstract: Sister Cristina Scuccia has become a sensation on the Italian version of the talent show “The Voice.”
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — A true if unlikely tale: Young woman enrolls at a drama school sponsored by nuns, where the artistic director is a former Italian erotic film actress who redirected her career after a religious awakening. The students are selected to perform before the pope at St. Peter’s Square, but during rehearsals the young woman fractures an ankle.

articles.headline: Twitter Plunges as More Shares Hit Market
articles.snippet: An analyst says insiders are selling shares as a lockup period comes to an end after the stock’s public offering last November.
articles.abstract: An analyst says insiders are selling shares as a lockup period comes to an end after the stock’s public offering last November.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Shares of Twitter went into free fall on Tuesday as early investors became eligible to sell their shares on the market for the first time. The company’s shares dropped 17.8 percent, to close at $31.85, their lowest level since the company’s initial public offering of stock in November.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Chinese Giant Alibaba Will Go Public, Listing in U.S.
articles.snippet: The e-commerce behemoth Alibaba Group filed paperwork in the U.S. to sell stock to the public, a coming-of-age for China’s booming Internet industry.
articles.abstract: The e-commerce behemoth Alibaba Group filed paperwork in the U.S. to sell stock to the public, a coming-of-age for China’s booming Internet industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:04 p.m. | The Chinese e-commerce behemoth Alibaba Group filed paperwork on Tuesday in the United States to sell stock to the public for the first time, in an embrace of the global capital markets that represents a coming-of-age for China’s booming Internet industry.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel, Michael J. de la Merced and Neil Gough

articles.headline: After Huge Alibaba Payday, a Test for Yahoo Executives
articles.snippet: Marissa Mayer, chief of Yahoo, will have to prove to Wall Street that she has a plan to save the company after it sells its stake in Alibaba.
articles.abstract: Marissa Mayer, chief of Yahoo, will have to prove to Wall Street that she has a plan to save the company after it sells its stake in Alibaba.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For Yahoo, the initial public offering of stock in the Alibaba Group will unlock the door to a giant trove of cash. Depending on the price of the deal, Yahoo most likely will receive $10 billion to $15 billion for the 9 percent stake in the Chinese e-commerce company that it is required to sell in the offering.

articles.headline: 2 Apollo Global Partners Are Said to Be Leaving
articles.snippet: The departures of partners from Apollo Global Management underscore the growing pains that Apollo is facing as it adjusts to life as a publicly traded company.
articles.abstract: The departures of partners from Apollo Global Management underscore the growing pains that Apollo is facing as it adjusts to life as a publicly traded company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apollo Global Management has climbed to the pinnacle of the private equity world, reaping billions of dollars in profit and raising a huge new buyout fund.

articles.headline: Big Profits at Alibaba, but Filing Has Gaps
articles.snippet: To put their own price on Alibaba, investors will most likely try to compare it against other technology companies. That may be difficult.
articles.abstract: To put their own price on Alibaba, investors will most likely try to compare it against other technology companies. That may be difficult.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Alibaba Group opened its books on Tuesday, revealing a company raking in extraordinary profits from its vast online marketplaces in China.

articles.headline: Russia Quietly Tightens Reins on Web With ‘Bloggers Law’
articles.snippet: Taking another step to restrict Russia’s Internet, President Vladimir V. Putin quietly signed a new law requiring popular online voices to register with the government.
articles.abstract: Taking another step to restrict Russia’s Internet, President Vladimir V. Putin quietly signed a new law requiring popular online voices to register with the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia has taken another major step toward restricting its once freewheeling Internet, as President Vladimir V. Putin quietly signed a new law requiring popular online voices to register with the government, a measure that lawyers, Internet pioneers and political activists said Tuesday would give the government a much wider ability to track who said what online.

articles.headline: At the U.N., a Free-for-All on Setting Global Goals
articles.snippet: The only thing keeping the world from agreeing on a new set of development objectives is the involvement of the whole world.
articles.abstract: The only thing keeping the world from agreeing on a new set of development objectives is the involvement of the whole world.
articles.lead_paragraph: What should the world’s priorities be? Is the most urgent task to guarantee everybody a minimum standard of subsistence? To reduce inequality? To combat global warming, perhaps at the expense of economic growth?

articles.headline: The Unlikely Ascent of Jack Ma, Alibaba’s Founder
articles.snippet: Jack Ma began his career as an English teacher. Today, two of his websites account for more than half of the packages shipped through China’s postal system.
articles.abstract: Jack Ma began his career as an English teacher. Today, two of his websites account for more than half of the packages shipped through China’s postal system.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The first time Jack Ma used the Internet, in 1995, he searched for “beer” and “China” but found no results. Intrigued, he created a basic web page for a Chinese translation service with a friend. Within hours, he received a handful of emails from around the world requesting information.
articles.byline: By Neil Gough and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Syrian Rebels Depart Homs District Under Deal
articles.snippet: The pullout, under the terms of a deal that gives the district to government forces, is a bitter defeat for the insurgents.
articles.abstract: The pullout, under the terms of a deal that gives the district to government forces, is a bitter defeat for the insurgents.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s third-largest city, Homs, was one of the first to hold large demonstrations against President Bashar al-Assad. Protesters there were among the first to take up arms against the state, and Homs neighborhoods were the first to suffer indiscriminate bombardment by government forces.

articles.headline: Yellen Won’t Be Pinned Down on Plans
articles.snippet: In generally upbeat testimony, the Fed chairwoman said that after a hard winter, the economy is “on track for solid growth in the current quarter.”
articles.abstract: In generally upbeat testimony, the Fed chairwoman said that after a hard winter, the economy is “on track for solid growth in the current quarter.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, told Congress on Wednesday that the economy was growing at a decent rate and that the Fed intended to continue the stimulus campaign that it considered at least partly responsible.

articles.headline: Putin Announces Pullback From Ukraine Border
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia pressed pause on Wednesday in what had begun to look like an inevitable march toward war in Ukraine, but world leaders questioned whether it was a feint.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia pressed pause on Wednesday in what had begun to look like an inevitable march toward war in Ukraine, but world leaders questioned whether it was a feint.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin, faced with rising violence in southeastern Ukraine that threatened to draw in the Russian Army at great cost and prompt severe new Western economic sanctions, pressed pause on Wednesday in what had started to look like an inevitable march toward war.
